title: How to Restring a Nylon String Classical Guitar

steps.title: Loosen and untie each string from the barrels in the headstock.
steps.content: Loosen and untie each string from the barrels in the headstock. Twist each of the tuning pegs by hand or using a winder until the string unravels completely. Untie the strings from the barrels or use scissors to clip them off. [1] X Research source If you’re in a hurry, clip the strings with scissors or wire cutters after detaching them from the headstock.

steps.title: Untie each string at the bridge and remove them.
steps.content: Untie each string at the bridge and remove them. Undo the knot at the bridge and push each string back through the hole in the bridge. Pull all of the strings out of the bridge and dispose of them. [2] X Research source Optionally, scrape up any grime on the fretboard with a popsicle stick. Clean the board with a toothbrush and a silicone-free guitar cleaner . Rub lemon oil on the fretboard with a soft cloth. [3] X Research source If you prefer to change the strings one at a time, remove each string before you tie on the new one. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Get a new pack of nylon classical guitar strings.
steps.content: Get a new pack of nylon classical guitar strings. Use normal tension nylon strings or strings made for classical guitars. Try to avoid steel strings or acoustic guitar strings that have a ball at one end. Try out different tension nylon strings to see if you like the sound better. [5] X Research source The tension in steel strings is much higher than nylon, which can put too much pressure on the neck, eventually causing it to bend or crack.

steps.title: Insert the thickest (E) string into the far left hole and create a loop.
steps.content: Insert the thickest (E) string into the far left hole and create a loop. Push the E string through the far left hole so that about 3 to 4 in (7.6 to 10.2 cm) sticks out towards the bottom of the guitar. [6] X Research source Take the end and wrap it behind the main length of the string so that the end is on the left side. Insert the end inside the loop created so that it faces to the right. [7] X Research source If one end of your new string has a rough, inflexible texture while the other end is smooth and flexible, use the smooth end to loop through the bridge. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Wrap the end of the string around the left edge of the loop once.
steps.content: Wrap the end of the string around the left edge of the loop once. Wrap the end of the E string around the left side of the loop 1 time. The bass strings on the left of your fretboard are thicker, and most only need to be wrapped around once to be secure. However, if your string is thinner, wrap it around 2 or 3 times. [9] X Research source To secure the string, professional guitarist Carlos Alonzo Rivera says “you slide one string in one end of the hole… Put in a little bit of the string there and then loop it back around. And then you have to tie a couple loops on the bridge, and then make sure the string is secure.” [10] X Expert Source Carlos Alonzo Rivera, MA Professional Guitarist Expert Interview. 18 August 2020.

steps.title: Hold the end over the next string’s hole and tighten the knot.
steps.content: Hold the end over the next string’s hole and tighten the knot. Press your finger over the end of the E string so it lies flat just above the hole in the bridge for the string next to it (the A string). Pull on the main length of string to tighten the knot. [11] X Research source If the end of the string is too long, trim it with a pair of scissors or wire cutters. Make sure the end of the string comes down under the bridge before you tighten it. This will help to ensure that your knot won’t come loose.

steps.title: Repeat the steps above with the 5th (A) and 4th (D) string.
steps.content: Repeat the steps above with the 5th (A) and 4th (D) string. Wrap the thicker strings next to the E string the same way. Make sure that the bottom of each loop dips under the bridge with their ends just above the hole in the bridge. Leave the 4th (D) string slightly loose so you can tuck the tail of the 3rd (G) string next to it underneath. [12] X Research source The A string will go over the end of the E string, tying it down. This prevents the end of your strings from whipping the guitar and scratching the surface. Alternatively, just clip the ends of each string so they won’t be long enough to whip the guitar. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Insert the thinnest (e) string, make a loop, and wrap its side 2 times.
steps.content: Insert the thinnest (e) string, make a loop, and wrap its side 2 times. Thread the thinnest string through the rightmost hole in the bridge. Wrap the end behind the main length so the end points right. Fold the end over the top of the string so that the end now points left. [14] X Research source Insert the end in the back of the loop created. Wrap the string around the right side of the loop twice. [15] X Research source This will create a secure knot around the bridge. This is the same process as above, except the end of the string points in the opposite direction.

steps.title: Hold the end over the hole of the next string and tighten the knot.
steps.content: Hold the end over the hole of the next string and tighten the knot. Hold your finger over the end of the e string so it lies flat just above the hole in the bridge for the string directly beside it (the B string). Gently pull on the main length of string to tighten the knot. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat the previous 2 steps with the 2nd (B) and 3rd (G) strings.
steps.content: Repeat the previous 2 steps with the 2nd (B) and 3rd (G) strings. This will create an even line of knots along the bridge, where the end of every string is tucked into the knot of the string next to it. [17] X Research source Leave the 3rd (G) string a little loose so you can tuck in the end of the 4th (D) string next to it.

steps.title: Tuck in the ends of the G and D strings and tighten them.
steps.content: Tuck in the ends of the G and D strings and tighten them. Take the end of the 3rd (G) string and tuck it over the hole of the 4th (D) string. Hold down the end and tighten the D string by pulling on its main length. Tuck the end of the D string over the hole of the G string, then tighten the G string by tugging gently on the main length above the bridge. [18] X Research source This will create a nice even tie, where both ends are tucked into the knot of the other string. Alternatively, repeat the first 3 steps with every string except the thinnest treble string (e). Follow the previous 4 steps for the e string and tuck its end into the B string’s knot. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Turn the tuning peg for the E string until the hole is facing up.
steps.content: Turn the tuning peg for the E string until the hole is facing up. Rotate the white barrel (capstan) inside the headstock until the hole faces directly up or follows the natural curve of the headstock. This allows you to see what you're doing. [20] X Research source Optionally, turn all the tuning pegs so that all the holes face upward and you don’t have to repeat this step.

steps.title: Thread the new E string through the top of the hole.
steps.content: Thread the new E string through the top of the hole. Push the end of the 6th (E) string down through the corresponding hole on barrel (capstan) in the neck. Catch the end with your finger so you can run it back through the gap above the capstan. [21] X Research source Some people prefer to insert the string through the hole twice so it’s more secure. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Run the E string back through the gap above the barrel (capstan).
steps.content: Run the E string back through the gap above the barrel (capstan). Push the end of the string upward with your fingers so it pokes up above the capstan you threaded it into. [23] X Research source Going above the capstan with the E string can give you more room to work. You can also push the string below the capstan—it depends on your preference.

steps.title: Pull the string down from the top of the fretboard to the first fret.
steps.content: Pull the string down from the top of the fretboard to the first fret. Pull the end of the string tight and place your finger on the white piece at the top of the fretboard. Pull the string down, keeping your finger at the same place along the string, until your finger reaches the first fret. This leaves slack in the middle of the neck so you can safely wind the string. [24] X Research source Alternatively, push the string to the right edge of the fretboard on the 1st fret.

steps.title: Cross the end over the main length and insert the end into the loop.
steps.content: Cross the end over the main length and insert the end into the loop. Tie an overhand knot on the barrel by crossing the end of the string over the main length on the other side of the barrel. Insert the end into the loop created and pull tight to create the knot. [25] X Research source

steps.title: Rotate the tuning peg to tighten the string and cut off the excess.
steps.content: Rotate the tuning peg to tighten the string and cut off the excess. Turn the tuning peg clockwise to tighten the string. When the string is tight and secured around the barrel, stop winding. Cut off any excess string with a pair of scissors or wire cutters. [26] X Research source Alternatively, use a pair of nail clippers to trim the ends of the strings.

steps.title: Repeat this process for every string.
steps.content: Repeat this process for every string. Working in order from the 6th (E) string to the 1st (e) string can make it easier to properly attach the new strings to the neck of the guitar. [27] X Research source Be careful not to tighten the strings so much that they snap. After you've attached all of your new strings, you’re ready to tune your guitar . Alternatively, you can attach the new E string before you remove the old A string and tune the guitar to itself. To do this, play the E string at the 5th fret and match it to the sound of the A string.

steps.title: Change your strings if they look dirty or sound dull or out of tune.
steps.content: Change your strings if they look dirty or sound dull or out of tune. Because each player and guitar is different, there’s no set standard for how often you need to restring your guitar. However, if your strings are discolored, the sound is dull, the strings won’t stay in tune, or they feel stiff or brittle, it might be time to switch them out. [28] X Research source Alternatively, change your strings every month if you play more than 3 hours per day, every 2 to 3 months if you play 1 to 2 hours per day, or every 4 months if you play less than an hour a day.
